nodes.bodyText: isn't this more like Completed request for {} blocks starting at {} from peer {}, got {} blocks. Next request starts from {}?
We don't actually count the number of blocks received - we just track what the last slot we got up to was. Reworded to talk about slots since that's technically what the range specifies.
so if no blocks were returned they must have all been empty

Yes.  The spec says a peer must return at least one block if it has one in the range.  So if we get no blocks either all slots were empty or the peer is lying.  If the peer is lying the next block we get from them will have a parent root that doesn't line up or we'll get to the peers head and not have the blocks they claim to have - in either case we wind up disconnecting the peer.
